DSRC Suggests
Dorm Expulsion
In Student Fire
The Dormitory Student Representative Council found two
Johns Hopkins dormitory students responsible for the fire in
the dormitory mailboxes in-February. By a majority vote of the
Council, the following was recommended to G. Wilson Shaffer,
Dean of the Homewood Schools:
1) thdt both students be immediately expelled from the
University dormitories,
2) that at the end of the present semester, both students
be allowed to apply to the
Dean of the Homewood
Schools for readmission,
and
3) that both students be required to pay for all damages and repairs through
the plant manger's office.
Dean Shaffer commended the
DSRC for finding those responsible for the fire. He concurred
in the decision that those responsible for the,fire should pay
for the damage-inflicted. "I feel,
however," stated the Dean,"That
the two students should not be
dismissed from the dormitory but
should remain under strict probation." This, the Dean felt, was
an even stricter punishment..

Though the average fraternity man may not heed
this warning, we warn that because of the present neighbor problem, the fraternity system at the Johns Hopkins
University is in danger of receiving by dint of city castigation more than a Saturday night social call from members of the city's finest. At the present time the Greeks,
like a peanut in a nutcracker, are wedged between the
general run of neighbors at one handle and the University
Heights Improvement Association at the other, while the
Baltimore City Police Force is poised, though reluctant,
to give a shattering squeeze.
It is unfair, though inevitable, that the present undergraduate fraternity man need take it on the chin not
only for his own actions, but primarily for the party
noise, drinking, and that which attends them, which has
accumulated over the past decade. And it is unfair that
eleven of the thirteen houses must nest uneasily in residential rows, whose homes are equipped with antiquated
porous walls, and whose residents are often the old guard
of the dying Waverly area pseudo-aristocracy. The anger
which has frothed off and on for over a decade along
Charles and St. Paul and Calvert is set to boil over. The
theatrics of Mr. Bennet and his wordy association we
know well. But how many fraternity men realize that at
least one fraternity has been warned that residents "all
up and down the three block area" (Calvert St. between
29th and 32nd) have formed a petition "to close your
doors"?
The Inter-fraternity Board is seriously considering
abolishing drinking during rush season, not only in an
effort to stifle neighborhood malcontent, but to aid in
calming the orientation of freshmen to Hopkinsian fraternity life. We agree and heartily approve that the move
would work out in the latter case, but we cannot agree
that the abolition of drinking during the rushing period,
or even an absolute clamp down upon the drinking of
alcoholic beverages at any time, would alleviate the neighbor problem.
It must be expected that in men of college age stereotyped fraternity antics will be the sometimes sister of the
gentlemen—with or without drinking. By this time the
neighbors in the area of chopped-up fraternity row have
been hardened against the word "fraternity," which to
them includesflirty back yards, lewd conversations heard
through walls, and typewriters clacking at three o'clock
in the morning, none of which are necessarily caused by
inebriation. "Fraternity" is a symbol of that which shatters the calm of a staid residential area.
The neighbors would like nothing better than to see
the houses booted onto campus; the fraternities, for their
own welfare, would be better off on campus, free from
neighborhood cranks, free from the immediate jurisdiction of the Baltimore police, and existing in the liberal
atmosphere of Homewood life. Not many years ago a
plan for such action was presented to the Inter-fraternity
Board, and unfortunately rejected. But such a plan is
needed now. Exactly where to place the houses on such
a small campus, we know not. How, we know not. Dean
Shaffer has stated that the possibility is presently an impossibility. Yet if the powers that be should strike, the
fraternity system at Hopkins may never recover. We find
no great leader to guide the Greeks over Charles Street
and into the promised land. Presently it appears that they
must sink or swim in their own maelstrom which extends
from University Parkway and Canterbury Road to Charles

Though the average fraternity man may not heed
this warning, we warn that because of the present neighbor problem, the fraternity system at the Johns Hopkins
University is in danger of receiving by dint of city castigation more than a Saturday night social call from members of the city's finest. At the present time the Greeks,
like a peanut in a nutcracker, are wedged between the
general run of neighbors at one handle and the University
Heights Improvement Association at the other, while the
Baltimore City Police Force is poised, though reluctant,
to give a shattering squeeze.
It is unfair, though inevitable, that the present undergraduate fraternity man need take it on the chin not
only for his own actions, but primarily for the party
noise, drinking, and that which attends them, which has
accumulated over the past decade. And it is unfair that
eleven of the thirteen houses must nest uneasily in residential rows, whose homes are equipped with antiquated
porous walls, and whose residents are often the old guard
of the dying Waverly area pseudo-aristocracy. The anger
which has frothed off and on for over a decade along
Charles and St. Paul and Calvert is set to boil over. The
theatrics of Mr. Bennet and his wordy association we
know well. But how many fraternity men realize that at
least one fraternity has been warned that residents "all
up and down the three block area" (Calvert St. between
29th and 32nd) have formed a petition "to close your
doors"?
The Inter-fraternity Board is seriously considering
abolishing drinking during rush season, not only in an
effort to stifle neighborhood malcontent, but to aid in
calming the orientation of freshmen to Hopkinsian fraternity life. We agree and heartily approve that the move
would work out in the latter case, but we cannot agree
that the abolition of drinking during the rushing period,
or even an absolute clamp down upon the drinking of
alcoholic beverages at any time, would alleviate the neighbor problem.
It must be expected that in men of college age stereotyped fraternity antics will be the sometimes sister of the
gentlemen—with or without drinking. By this time the
neighbors in the area of chopped-up fraternity row have
been hardened against the word "fraternity," which to
them includesflirty back yards, lewd conversations heard
through walls, and typewriters clacking at three o'clock
in the morning, none of which are necessarily caused by
inebriation. "Fraternity" is a symbol of that which shatters the calm of a staid residential area.
The neighbors would like nothing better than to see
the houses booted onto campus; the fraternities, for their
own welfare, would be better off on campus, free from
neighborhood cranks, free from the immediate jurisdiction of the Baltimore police, and existing in the liberal
atmosphere of Homewood life. Not many years ago a
plan for such action was presented to the Inter-fraternity
Board, and unfortunately rejected. But such a plan is
needed now. Exactly where to place the houses on such
a small campus, we know not. How, we know not. Dean
Shaffer has stated that the possibility is presently an impossibility. Yet if the powers that be should strike, the
fraternity system at Hopkins may never recover. We find
no great leader to guide the Greeks over Charles Street
and into the promised land. Presently it appears that they
must sink or swim in their own maelstrom which extends
from University Parkway and Canterbury Road to Charles
